Award.AwardTitle: CRII: Cyberlearning: Connecting Web Annotations and Progressive Online Discourse in Science Classrooms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers, teachers, and curriculum experts continually seek ways to improve school science. This CRII project aims to bring school science into closer alignment with real-world science through deeper connections to public scientific discourse. The PI and his team will harness recent Open Web technologies to build a platform to transform scientific engagement in classrooms with the broader cyberspace. With various theory-driven supports provided by this platform, students will work collectively to build scientific understanding on the Open Web based upon a model of knowledge building. The project will produce design innovations that enable students to: navigate complex Web spaces and make sense of real-world problems collaboratively; deal with complex scientific idea landscapes beyond school walls; and, engage in sophisticated scientific practices not unlike those of real-world laboratories. This project will contribute to the goal of preparing a competent science workforce and a scientifically literate citizenry as emphasized in the NSF Strategic Plan 2014-2018. During the project, the PI will also contribute to teacher professional development activities, organize design and research workshops, and mentor emerging scholars from diverse backgrounds.

Following a design-based research approach, this project will develop a technology prototype, Progressive Discourse on the Open Web (ProDow), to bridge discourse in an existing knowledge-building environment and the Open Web through collaborative social annotations. This work is grounded in decades of research on progressive knowledge-building discourse, understanding of how students learn science, and the latest Web technologies. The research objectives include: (a) identifying design principles and software architecture for ProDow; (b) exploring student use of ProDow for progressive knowledge-building discourse in science; and (c) determining whether, and under what conditions ProDow can support science learning. Through design inquiry and empirical investigations in science classrooms, this project will contribute to cyberlearning research by providing new means to support collaborative learning. Through a series of participatory design workshops with teachers and researchers, design solutions and functioning prototypes will be developed. Empirical investigations will take place in science classrooms in a high school with an ethnically and economically diverse student body in Minneapolis. Classroom observations, interviews, and system logs will be collected to investigate how students leverage social annotations to sustain their scientific discourse. This project will lead to three major research outcomes: (a) design principles for integrating social annotations into group knowledge building in science classrooms; (b) empirical knowledge of high-school students' use of social annotations in progressive scientific inquiry; and (c) the creation of a new technology prototype, ProDow, that embodies the design principles and empirical findings of this investigation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Technologies devised for formal education are often based on closed cyber-systems disconnected from the public. Conceptualizing learning as a coherent part of one?s social life, this project proposed to bridge science inquiry in high school classrooms with public discourse on the web through modern web technologies. During the two-year project period, a research team from the University of Minnesota developed a technology prototype named IdeaMagnets in close collaboration with science teachers from a high school in Minneapolis. With the IdeaMagnets tool, high schoolers critically examined a rich collection of web sources about climate change, annotated these sources in relation to a science unit on Energy, and used their annotations to collaboratively build knowledge in an online environment named Knowledge Forum. Overall, this project has led to three major research outcomes including (a) a new technology prototype, namely IdeaMagnets, that bridges public discourse with student work in the classroom; (b) pedagogical designs that combine public discourse with science inquiry in classrooms; and (c) empirical knowledge about highschoolers' use of IdeaMagnets to make sense of public discourse and support their science learning.

To begin with, the project generated a software prototype, IdeaMagnets, which is integrated in Knowledge Forum, a learning technology that is used in classrooms around the world. Through a series of participatory design workshops, a group of science teachers were involved as co-designers so that their insights and expertise could be reflected in the designed technology. Multiple design principles were also distilled and used to guide the prototype design; these principles include: (a) turning any web object into an object of learning discourse; (b) enabling ideas and knowledge artifacts to move across web spaces; (c) providing multiple entry points to a common discourse; and (d) promoting boundary-crossing between discourse spaces. These design principles are embodied in the IdeaMagnets design (see the attached image) and would inform the design of learning technologies that extend learner engagement into fuller participation in the broader cyberspace. 

With the IdeaMagnets tool, empirical investigations were conducted in a Minneapolis high school with an ethnically and economically diverse student body. The project team worked closely with participating teachers to meaningfully contextualize IdeaMagnets in their science classrooms. The  same co-design approach was adopted to engage the participating teacher to integrate IdeaMagnets with his existing pedagogical practices. Over two academic quarters, five classes of high school students conducted science inquiry about energy and climate change in the context of the Green New Deal that was trending in the public discourse. Research questions we asked included: Whether, and under what conditions, could IdeaMagnets support science learning? In particular, we asked whether students were able to connect classroom discourse with public discourse to better their learning engagement. Results showed students were able to build a learning culture that involved the use of web annotations to make sense of a wide range of public sources; with IdeaMagnets, they were able to use these web sources in a constructive manner to advance their knowledge goals. The designed tool and pedagogical strategies allowed students to navigate complex web space, critically examine information they encountered online, and use a diverse set of ideas they collectively gathered to deepen their work that was closely connected with the public discourse on climate change.

Broader impacts

This project involved five classes of students from an urban high school in learning about energy and climate systems for an extended period of time. With the IdeaMagnets tool and extensive pedagogical supports, students contextualized their learning in the public discourse on climate change and the Green New Deal. By purposefully connecting school work with public discourse, this project aimed to make science learning more engaging, meaningful, and personally relevant for students. By doing so, this project contributed to the goal of preparing a competent STEM workforce and a STEM-literate citizenry as emphasized in the NSF Strategic Plan. During the project, a research-practice partnership has also been formed between participating teachers and the research team. Two teachers who participated in this project led a professional development workshop in the school district to introduce our collaborative work. Finally, the developed IdeaMagnets tool is fully integrated in the Knowledge Forum environment and has been made available to a broad international community (see https://ikit.org/kbi/). Educators from multiple schools and universities from the US, Canada, and Hong Kong have incorporated this tool in their teaching. 

 

Key references

Chang, Y.-H., Chen, B., Ouyang, F., Groos, D., & Alton, J. (2019, April). Teachers as co-designers of a knowledge building environment. Paper presented at the 2019 Knowledge Building Summer Institute, Toronto, Canada.

Chen, B. (2019). Designing for networked collaborative discourse: An UnLMS approach. TechTrends, 63(2), 194?201. https://doi.org/10.1007/s11528-018-0284-7
